/NTgCalls/Advanced Methods/Send External.title: Send External Frame
/NTgCalls/Advanced Methods/Send External.description: This method allows sending an external audio or video frame to the WebRTC connection.

example.code:
from ntgcalls import NTgCalls
from ntgcalls import StreamDevice
from ntgcalls import FrameData
from datetime import datetime
...

app = NTgCalls()
...
pcm16_le_data = ...

await app.send_external_frame(
    -1001185324811,
    StreamDevice.MICROPHONE,
    pcm16_le_data,
    FrameData(
        int(datetime.now().timestamp()),
        0,
        0,
        0,
    )
)

/NTgCalls/Build Guide.xml.title: Introduction
/NTgCalls/Build Guide.xml.description: Being a modern library, requires CMake 3.31+ to be built on your system, on Linux is required at least CLang 20+, libasound2 and libpulse-dev. We recommend using the latest versions of both CMake and CLang. Below, we will guide you through the step-by-step process of installing the prerequisites required to compile NTgCalls on your operating system. In this section, you'll learn how to clone the NTgCalls repository and build the library from source. To begin building NTgCalls from source, you need to clone the GitHub repository. Follow these steps to clone the repo: Now that you have successfully installed all the required prerequisites for NTgCalls, it's time to build the library. Follow these steps to compile NTgCalls on your system. For developers looking to use NTgCalls with C and C++, we provide C Bindings. Follow these steps to compile NTgCalls with C Bindings in either Release or Debug mode: NTgCalls offers Python Bindings, facilitating seamless integration with Python. Follow these steps to compile NTgCalls with Python Bindings: NTgCalls offers Java for Android Bindings, facilitating seamless integration with Java for Android. Follow these steps to compile NTgCalls with Java for Android Bindings:

/NTgCalls/Callback Registration.xml.title: Callback Registration
/NTgCalls/Callback Registration.xml.description: Callbacks registration allows you to specify custom functions to be executed when specific events occur or conditions are met within your application. These events might include changes in call status, media state updates, or other critical moments in the NTgCalls library's operation. When registering callbacks, keep in mind that each registration replaces the previously set callback.

/NTgCalls/Getting Started.xml.title: Getting Started
/NTgCalls/Getting Started.xml.description: This section provides documentation for the NTgCalls C API, which allows you to use NTgCalls in various programming languages, including C, C++, Go, Rust, Deno, and more. Below, you will find detailed information about the initialization and cleanup functions. To get started with NTgCalls in your application, you need to initialize the library using the function. This function sets up the necessary resources and prepares NTgCalls for use. To clean up and release the resources used by NTgCalls, you should call the function. This function deallocates memory and performs necessary cleanup operations. You can retrieve the version of the NTgCalls library currently in use using the function. This function returns a string containing the version number. Retrieve library version

/NTgCalls/Quick Start.xml.title: Quick Start
/NTgCalls/Quick Start.xml.description: Welcome to this section, which is primarily intended for developers who are moderately experienced or seeking to perform a porting in their language using C bindings. If you are new to Python development, we strongly recommend using Py-TgCalls . However, if you fall into the aforementioned categories, you can find an example of usage with the various porting below. Looking for real-world implementations? Below is a selection of bots actively maintained and recommended by the community, all using NTgCalls/Py-TgCalls under the hood. These can be a great source of inspiration or even a solid starting point for your own project. In the following section, we present a comprehensive catalog of libraries, thoughtfully crafted by the community and officially endorsed, all of which leverage the robust capabilities of NTgCalls. What we've just seen are simplified ports of NTgCalls. However, now let's delve deeper! In the upcoming pages, we'll explore NTgCalls in a step-by-step manner, covering how it functions, how to install it, and more. Are you feeling eager to continue? You can take a shortcut to the Call Methods section and return later to delve into more details.

/PyTgCalls/Basic Methods/Idle.xml.title: Idle
/PyTgCalls/Basic Methods/Idle.xml.description: This function will run indefinitely in order to block the main script execution and prevent it from exiting while having client(s) that are still running in the background. PyTgCalls works by keeping your handlers in a pool of worker threads, which run concurrently outside the main thread. Calling idle() will ensure that the client(s) remain active, by preventing the main script from ending until you decide to quit. Once a signal is received (e.g.: from CTRL+C) the function will terminate and your main script will continue.

example.code:
from pytgcalls import Client
from pytgcalls import idle
...

app1 = PyTgCalls(client1)
app2 = PyTgCalls(client2)
app3 = PyTgCalls(client3)

...  # Set handlers up

app1.start()
app2.start()
app3.start()

idle()

/PyTgCalls/Decorators.xml.title: Decorators
/PyTgCalls/Decorators.xml.description: While still being methods bound to the PyTgCalls class, decorators hold a special significance that justifies a dedicated page. Decorators allow you to register callback functions for handling updates in a much easier and cleaner way. All you need to do is add the decorators on top of your functions. Decorator for handling incoming HTTP events. You have set too many decorators.

example.code:
from pytgcalls import PyTgCalls
from pytgcalls.types import Update
from pytgcalls import filters as call_filters
...
client = # Here Your MTProto Client
app = PyTgCalls(client)

@app.on_update(call_filters.stream_end())
async def handler(client: PyTgCalls, update: Update):
    print(update)

app.run()

/PyTgCalls/Examples.xml.title: Examples
/PyTgCalls/Examples.xml.description: This page contains example scripts to demonstrate how PyTgCalls looks like. Every script is working right away (assuming you correctly set up your credentials), meaning you can simply copy-paste them and run. The only things you have to modify are session names and target chats, where applicable. The examples listed below can be treated as building blocks for your own applications and are designed to be simple enough to give you a basic idea.

/PyTgCalls/Filters.xml.title: Filters
/PyTgCalls/Filters.xml.description: Filters are objects that can be used to filter the content of incoming updates. Read more about how filters work.

items.description:
Easily create a custom filter.

                Custom filters give you extra control over which updates are allowed or not to be processed by your handlers. Filter updates for yourself. Filter updates for when a stream ends. Filter updates coming from one or more chats.
                You can use Filter specific type of chat updates. Filter updates for when a call participant joins, leaves or is updated. Filter updates for when stream frames are received.

/PyTgCalls/Handling Updates.xml.title: Handling Updates
/PyTgCalls/Handling Updates.xml.description: Calling API methods sequentially is cool, but what if, for example, the list of participants changes? This page covers updates and how to handle such events in PyTgCalls. Lets have a look at how they work. First of all, let's define what these updates are. As hinted earlier, updates are events that happen in PyTgCalls, such as joining a group call, changes in the participant list, stream ended etc. They are meant to notify you about a new specific state change. These updates are handled by registering one or more callback functions in your app using Decorators . Each handler deals with a specific event. When a matching update arrives from Telegram or NTgCalls, the registered callback function will be called back by the framework, and its body will execute. To explain how handlers work, let's examine the one that will be in charge of handling updates, which occur when a video stream ends. The same setup logic is shared with every type of handler, and you should not have troubles settings them up once you have learned from this section. The most elegant way to register a stream end handler is by using the on_stream_end() decorator: The defined function, which accepts two arguments (client, update), will be executed whenever a new update arrives. The add_handler() method takes any handler instance that wraps around your defined callback function and registers it in your Client. It is useful in case you want to programmatically add handlers.

example.code:
from pytgcalls import PyTgCalls, filters
from pytgcalls.types import Update
from pytgcalls.types import MediaStream
...
app = PyTgCalls(client)

@app.on_update(filters.stream_end())
async def my_handler(client: PyTgCalls, update: Update):
    if isinstance(update, StreamVideoEnded):
        await pytgcalls.play(
            -1001185324811,
            'http://docs.evostream.com/sample_content/assets/sintel1m720p.mp4',
        )

app.run()

/PyTgCalls/Install Guide.xml.title: Install Guide
/PyTgCalls/Install Guide.xml.description: Being a modern Python library, requires Python 3.9+ to be installed in your system. We recommend using the latest versions of both Python 3 and pip. The easiest way to install and upgrade PyTgCalls to its latest stable version is by using pip: PyTgCalls is always evolving: although new releases on PyPI are only published when a significant number of changes are added, this doesnt mean you cant try new features right now! In case youd like to try out the latest PyTgCalls features, the is constantly updated with new changes; you can install the development version straight from the branch using this command (note master.zip in the link): To verify that PyTgCalls is correctly installed, open a Python shell and import it. If no errors show up you are good to go.

example.code: $ pip3 install -U py-tgcalls

/PyTgCalls/Quick Start.xml.title: Quick Start
/PyTgCalls/Quick Start.xml.description: The next few steps serve as a quick start for all new Pythoneers that want to see PyTgCalls in action as quickly as possible. Lets go! That was just a brief overview that barely scratched the surface! In the following few pages of the introduction, well have a much more in-depth look at what we have just done. Are you feeling eager to continue? You can take a shortcut to Call Methods and return later to learn more details.

parameters.name: bitrate
parameters.description: Audio sample rate (0-96000, max allowed by PCM16L).

parameters.name: channels
parameters.description: Audio channel count (1-2, max allowed by PCM16L).

parameters.name: from_quality(quality
parameters.description: This method was deprecated on PyTgCalls 1.2.X, use directly AudioQuality in MediaStream instead Create an AudioParameters instance from an AudioQuality enumeration.

parameters.name: path
parameters.description: The audio file path or shell command (PCM16L format only).

parameters.name: media_path
parameters.description:
The audio, video, image or media device path. audio_parameters: Optional[Union[pytgcalls.types.raw.AudioParameters, pytgcalls.types.AudioQuality]]
Streams audio parameters. video_parameters: Optional[Union[pytgcalls.types.raw.VideoParameters, pytgcalls.types.VideoQuality]]
Streams video parameters.

parameters.name: audio_path
parameters.description: The audio or input audio device path.

parameters.name: audio_flags
parameters.description: Flag used to control the handling of the audio stream in the media. It allows the system to decide whether to automatically detect, ignore, or require the audio stream.

parameters.name: video_flags
parameters.description:
Flag used to control the handling of the video stream in the media. It allows the system to decide whether to automatically detect, ignore, or require the video stream. headers: Optional[dict[str, str]]
HTTP connections headers.

parameters.name: audio
parameters.description:
The speaker device, audio file or if it should be sent as updates. audio_parameters: Optional[Union[pytgcalls.types.raw.AudioParameters, pytgcalls.types.AudioQuality]]
Streams audio parameters.

parameters.name: frame_rate
parameters.description: Frames per second (FPS) for video playback.

parameters.name: adjust_by_height
parameters.description: Adjust the video resolution by height instead of width.

parameters.name: from_quality(quality
parameters.description: This method was deprecated on PyTgCalls 1.2.X, use directly VideoQuality in MediaStream instead Create an VideoParameters instance from an VideoQuality enumeration.

parameters.name: path
parameters.description: The video file path or shell command (YUV420P format only).

/PyTgCalls/Stream Methods/Mute.xml.title: Mute
/PyTgCalls/Stream Methods/Mute.xml.description: This method allows muting the userbot via MTProto APIs.

example.code:
from pytgcalls import Client
from pytgcalls import idle
...

app = PyTgCalls(client)
app.start()

...  # Call API methods

app.mute(
    -1001185324811,
)

idle()

items.name: chat_id
items.description: Can be direct id or a username

exception pytgcalls.exceptions.NoMTProtoClient
This method can only be called with a valid MTProto client set.
exception pytgcalls.exceptions.ClientNotStarted
Ensure you have started the process with start() before calling this method.
exception pytgcalls.exceptions.NotInCallError
This error occurs when attempting to execute an action on a call that you have not joined.

/PyTgCalls/Using Filters.xml.title: Using Filters
/PyTgCalls/Using Filters.xml.description: So far weve seen how to register a decorator function that executes every time an update comes from the server, but theres much more than that to come. Here well discuss filters . Filters enable a fine-grain control over what kind of updates are allowed or not to be passed in your callback functions, based on their inner details. Lets start right away with a simple example: Filters can be used in a more advanced way by inverting and combining more filters together using bitwise operators , and : Here are some examples:

/PyTgCalls/Using Handlers.xml.title: Using Handlers
/PyTgCalls/Using Handlers.xml.description: Handlers are used to instruct PyTgCalls to execute a specific function when a certain event occurs. For a much more convenient way to handle updates, you can use the decorators instead. To register a handler, you need to use the method. This method takes two arguments: the first is the callback function, and the second is the filter. To remove a handler, you need to use the method. This method takes the callback function as its only argument.

example.code:
from pytgcalls import PyTgCalls
from pytgcalls.types import Update
from pytgcalls import filters as call_filters
...

client = # Here Your MTProto Client
app = PyTgCalls(client)

async def handler(client: PyTgCalls, update: Update):
    print(update)
...
app.add_handler(handler, call_filters.stream_end())
...
